p: Viruses are useful model systems for studying parallel evolution and adaptation. Many viruses, particularly RNA viruses, can adapt rapidly due to a combination of high mutation rates, large population sizes, short generation times, and large mutational selection coefficients [ 10 •• ]. Further, the small genomes of RNA viruses (and some DNA viruses) may limit the range of genetic solutions available to viruses as they respond to environmental change. In contrast, the larger genomes of DNA viruses, such as Myxoma [ 11], may offer more potential genetic routes to the same phenotype.
